questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

Review the Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) profile signature settings.
Which statement is correct in adding the FTP.Login.Failed signature to the IPS sensor profile?

comments.content:
"pass" is only default action

To explain this: the Pass action on the specific signature would only be chosen, if the Action (on the top) was set to Default. But instead its set to Block, se the action is will be to block and drop.

discussion.content:
A is correct. FortiGate_Security_6.4 page 525 and 529.
"pass" is only default action
A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
Is A the acción is block
A is correct. FortiGate Security 6.4 page 529. "Select the block to silently drop mathematical traffic from any of the signatures included in the entry"

Selected Answer: A
A is correct because action is "block" and not "default" on the rule

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.
Selected Answer : A
Selected Answer: A

Selected Answer: A
Since the action is Blocked the answer is A

Selected Answer: A
Action is drop, signature default action is listed only in the signature, it would only match if action was set to default.
I vote for A, by adding this signature it will overwrite the default setting with the Block action. Silent drop means it will break the TCP session state without sending a FIN to the sender.

Selected Answer: A
A like others stated
A is correct, test in lab
D is correct as it says traffic matching with IPS signature "FTP.login" and action is passed, all others will be dropped except matching signature FTP.loginfailed.
D is the correct,,
In option A, does anyone really know what they mean by silently dropped considering that the blocked packets will be logged?

comments.content: the client or server will not be notified for the dropped packet, maybe

discussion.content: A is correct, Default signature action is ALLOW but Block will override it
A is correct
A is correct.
A is the correct answer. As the mandatory action is BLOCK!

choices.D: Traffic matching the signature will be allowed and logged.
choices.B: The signature setting uses a custom rating threshold.
choices.A: Traffic matching the signature will be silently dropped and logged.
choices.C: The signature setting includes a group of other signatures.

choices.B: FortiGate acts as an HTTP reverse proxy.
choices.A: FortiGate acts as an FDS server.

discussion.content: B is correct. FortiGate_Security_6.4 page 576

Selected Answer: B
B.

Fortigate security Pg 583
B is correct
D. Fortigate acts as router its correct?
B is correct
In web-only mode, the FortiGate unit acts as a secure HTML5 HTTPS gateway and authenticates remote users as members of a user group.

questions.question_text: How does FortiGate act when using SSL VPN in web mode?

discussion.content:
By default does not match vip in deny policy for destination all. So 2 options wehave
1. Enable match vip in the Deny policy.
2. Add destination as webserver in deny policy

comments.content: But there is written that Set the destination address as vip object look "FortiGate Security 6.4 Self Study" page 160.

discussion.content: C & D is correct answer. You can find the answer in "FortiGate Security 6.4 Self Study" page 159.
C and D is correct

Selected Answer: CD
C e D são verdadeiras
https://community.fortinet.com/t5/FortiGate/Technical-Tip-Firewall-does-not-block-incoming-WAN-to-LAN/ta-p/189641
C D - FortiGate Security 6.4 Self Study. Pag 160
Should be more precise saying the VIP of the WebServer instead of the web server.
C, D are correct
C and D are correct

choices.B: Set the Destination address as Deny_IP in the Allow-access policy.
choices.A: Disable match-vip in the Deny policy.
choices.C: Enable match-vip in the Deny policy.
choices.D: Set the Destination address as Web_server in the Deny policy.

comments.content:
on pag 315 it says how to use the certificate to identify a Persone or a Device.
This question is different.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
"...FortiGate parses server name indication (SNI) from client Hello..."
"If there is no SNI exchanged, then FortiGate identifies the server by the value in the Subject field or SAN"
Fortigate Security 6.4 Study Guide, page 328
A, C & D are correct
The right answer is A,C and D
A,C,D is correct one

A,C,D are correct. Fortigate uses the server name indication (SNI) to discern the hostname of the SSL server at the beginning of the SSL handshake. If there is no SNI, Forigate looks at the subject and subject alternative name fields.

choices.A: The subject field in the server certificate
choices.C: The server name indication (SNI) extension in the client hello message
choices.E: The host field in the HTTP header
choices.B: The serial number in the server certificate
choices.D: The subject alternative name (SAN) field in the server certificate
